meta.title: 6. CPU Scheduling
meta.path: quizzes/Computer Science/2/1/Operatings Systems/أسئلة الدكتور المحلولة/6. CPU Scheduling.json

questions.q: Given n processes to be scheduled on one processor, how many different possible schedules exist?
questions.explanation: With n processes, there are n! (n factorial = n × (n-1) × (n-2) × ... × 2 × 1) possible orderings or schedules.

questions.q: What is the difference between preemptive and nonpreemptive scheduling?
questions.explanation: Preemptive scheduling can interrupt a running process and switch to another. Nonpreemptive scheduling waits for the process to finish its CPU burst before switching.
questions.answer: Preemptive allows interrupting a process and allocating CPU to another; nonpreemptive requires the process to relinquish CPU voluntarily

questions.q: For the processes with arrival times P1(0.0, 8), P2(0.4, 4), P3(1.0, 1), what is the average turnaround time using FCFS scheduling?
questions.explanation: Using First-Come-First-Served, P1 runs first, then P2, then P3. Remember turnaround time is finishing time minus arrival time. FCFS gives 10.53.

questions.q: Using the same processes from the previous question, what is the average turnaround time with SJF (Shortest Job First) scheduling?
questions.explanation: SJF schedules P1 first (it's available at time 0), then P3 (shortest remaining), then P2, giving an average turnaround time of 9.53.

questions.q: What advantage is there in having different time-quantum sizes at different levels of a multilevel queueing system?
questions.explanation: Processes needing frequent servicing (like editors) benefit from small time quanta. Processes not requiring frequent servicing can use larger quanta, reducing context switches and improving efficiency.
questions.answer: Interactive processes can use small quanta for frequent servicing while batch processes use larger quanta for efficiency

questions.q: The FCFS algorithm is equivalent to the RR (Round Robin) algorithm with an infinite time quantum.
questions.explanation: With an infinite time quantum, Round Robin never preempts, allowing each process to run to completion in order of arrival, which is exactly First-Come-First-Served behavior.

questions.q: What relationship exists between Priority scheduling and SJF (Shortest Job First)?
questions.explanation: SJF is a special case of priority scheduling where priority is inversely related to predicted CPU burst time - the shortest job gets the highest priority.
options: In SJF, the shortest job has the highest priority
Priority scheduling is always faster than SJF
SJF cannot be expressed as priority scheduling

questions.q: Why does a scheduling algorithm that favors processes with least recent processor time favor I/O-bound programs without starving CPU-bound programs?
questions.explanation: I/O-bound programs are favored due to their short CPU burst requests, but they frequently relinquish the CPU to perform I/O operations, giving CPU-bound programs opportunities to run.
questions.answer: I/O-bound programs have short CPU bursts (favored by the algorithm) but relinquish CPU frequently (allowing CPU-bound programs to eventually run)

questions.q: What is the difference between PCS (Process-Contention Scope) and SCS (System-Contention Scope) scheduling?
questions.explanation: PCS scheduling is how the thread library schedules user threads onto available LWPs. SCS is where the OS schedules kernel threads. On one-to-one threading models, PCS and SCS are the same.
options: PCS is local thread library scheduling of threads onto LWPs; SCS is OS scheduling of kernel threads
SCS only works on single-processor systems
PCS is used only for real-time systems

questions.q: Is it necessary to bind a real-time thread to an LWP in a many-to-many threading model for scheduling purposes?
questions.explanation: Yes. Without binding, a user thread may have to compete for an available LWP before being scheduled, introducing latency. Binding ensures the real-time thread can be scheduled immediately without waiting for an LWP.

questions.q: In the traditional UNIX scheduler with Priority = (recent CPU usage / 2) + base (base=60), if P1 has recent CPU usage of 40, P2 has 18, and P3 has 10, what are their new priorities? Does this raise or lower the priority of CPU-bound processes?
questions.explanation: With higher numbers meaning lower priority in UNIX, the priorities are 80, 69, and 65 respectively. CPU-bound processes have higher recent usage, resulting in higher priority numbers (lower actual priority).
questions.answer: P1=80, P2=69, P3=65. The scheduler lowers the relative priority of CPU-bound processes
